title: DataViz
text:
Hi, welcome to DataViz!


This website is a collection of data, projects, and visualizations on topics that I find interesting and relevant. All the data and code here are publicly available so feel free to explore, learn, and use them for your own projects.

 jump right in →

title: jp monteagudo
text:
Hello there,

Thanks for stopping by!
I’m an aspiring epidemiologist currently pursuing post-graduate studies in Epidemiology at Liberty University. I’m interested in clinical epidemiology, epidemiological research methods, infectious diseases, pharmaco-epidemiology and nutritional epidemiology.
I love statistics and the R programming language. I’m currently taking a deep dive into generalized linear models, causal inference and data visualization.
Nowadays, I work as a Learning & Development Specialist conducting a pilot study analyzing the impact of new hire training on performance in a fast-paced contact center environment.

title: Remake of visual representation of statistical data graphed in 1644 by Michael van Langren
text:

title: what i use
text: A collection of programming tools, open–access books, sites, and data visualization principles in R from the web.

title: what i use
text:
Software and Tools


R and Rstudio for statistical graphs and data analysis.

QGIS, a free and open source software for geospatial data visualization.

Tableau Public — Tableau’s free version for interactive data visualization.

Datawrapper — A drag–and–drop tool to create simple and interactive charts.

title: what i use
text:
Books
Open–Access books

“Data Visualization: A practical Introduction” by Kieran Healy. A book on data visualization principles and techniques in R.
“ggplot2: Elegant Graphics for Data Analysis” by Hadley Wickham. A book on ggplot2 package for data visualization in R.
“R Graphics Cookbook” by Winston Chang. A practical guide to create hundreds of graphs using simple recipes.
“Geocomputation with R” by Robin Lovelace, Jakub Nowosad, and Jannes Muenchow. A book on spatial data analysis and visualization in R.
“Introduction to GIS” by Michael T. M. Gimond. A book on GIS principles and techniques in ArcGIS and R.
“Efficient R Programming” by Colin Gillespie and Robin Lovelace. A book on efficient programming techniques in R.
“Analyzing US Census Data” by Kyle Walker. A book on US Census data analysis and visualization using the tidycensus and other packages in R.
“The Elements of Typographic Style” by Robert Bringhurst. A book on typography principles.
Not so Open–Access books

“Practical Typography” A book on typography principles and techniques in web design offered free of charge.
“The Visual Display of Quantitative Information” by Edward Tufte. A book on data visualization principles and techniques.
“Beautiful Evidence” by Edward Tufte. A book to understand, recognize and create beautiful in data.

title: what i use
text:
Galleries


R Graph Gallery — A collection of hundreds of graphs and their code in R.

ggplot2 extensions — A collection of ggplot2 extensions for data visualization in R.

Tableau Public Gallery — A collection of interactive data visualizations in Tableau Public.

QGIS Map Gallery — A collection of maps created in QGIS.

title: what i use
text:
Palettes


R Color Palettes — A compehensive list of R discrete color palettes

Iwanthue — A cool way to generate optimally distinct color palettes for data scientists.

Poolors — A collection of the most and least used color palettes by graphic designers.

Rayshader — Not exactly a palette but a package to create 2D and 3D visualizations in R.
